comment.author: 84511729@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/8468254@N02] Early plates weren't sensitive to much except blue, so even green would appear dark. However given the appearance of the foliage in the shot, I doubt that's the case here, and it's probably just a lack of red sensitivity - an orthochromatic emulsion. 

Dark red-brown eyes would probably appear very dark. Also you shouldn't discount the effect of the long exposure (again, see the foliage) in making eyes look weird as people blink or move their eyes involuntarily..

comment.author: 14302637@N08

comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 20727502@N00
comment._content: You have to look at the enumerators building returns to spot the "big house" in Kildalton. The 1911 enumerators return shows that it has 79 rooms and the "head of the household" (in the absense of the Earl) is listed as Jessie Briffin. She seems to oversee the 9 or so servants who live in the main house. The rest are in outbuildings and local houses on the demesne. (The entirety of which, unsurprisingly, has the listed landowner as the "Earl of Bessborough") It might be fun to put faces to the names. Or vice versa. But it's actually difficult to see continuity (and therefore surmise seniority or roles) when looking back to the 1901 census. So, even if we could spot the main housekeeper in the photo, it may be Ms Briffin. Or her predecessor. Interestingly also called Jessie, but a Ms Jessie Forrest.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/20727502@N00] I'm reading that as Brittin (not being picky, just in case anyone starts searching for a Briffin.
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 45618415@N05
comment._content: Interesting how the servants seem to be mainly Church of Ireland.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: Yes, well, you couldn't be letting the wild Irish into your house.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: I actually found it more interesting that there were a couple of CoE servants. I found it odd both that they were there and that they were listed separately, as it's not a different church as such, but just a different administrative branch of the Anglican communion.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: Ah. "The Church of Ireland made provision in 1870 for its own government, led by a General Synod, and with financial management by a Representative Church Body. With disestablishment, the Church's representation in the House of Lords also ceased." That would explain it. They were separate churches by the time this picture was taken. I bet the CoE ones still went to the local CoI church though.

comment.author: 77199267@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] that explains why I couldn't find a census entry in Kilkenny!

comment.author: 45618415@N05
comment._content: I seem to recall an episode of RTE's 'The History Show' dealing with Big Houses and servant life.  There was definitely a preference for Protestant and even British senior servants.  In many places there was a reluctance for locals to be too closely associated with the 'Big House' and servants were brought in from outside the neighbourhood.

comment.author: 63844591@N04
comment._content: Bessborough House is in Piltown Co Kilkenny, about 10 miles from Waterford on the road to Carrick on Suir. The house is now called Kildalton Agricultural College
